title: 111_hr5770
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment Implementation Act of 2010". The Congress declares the increasing accessibility of the Arctic Ocean to shipping due to thinning ice cover and technological advancements. It is in the interests of the United States to ensure safe, environmentally protective, and secure shipping in the Arctic Ocean and adjacent seas. The United States aims to protect Arctic shipping, ensure secure access for research vessels, maintain peaceful relations, establish international cooperation for reliable shipping, and provide mariners aids to navigation. The United States seeks to protect Arctic shipping and ensure secure access for research vessels, emphasizing the need for coordinated shipping regulations to safeguard national interests. International cooperation models exist, such as joint administration of waterways and cooperation with the Russian Federation for fisheries enforcement. The United States has interests in the Arctic and Bering Sea regions, including joint administration of the St. Lawrence Seaway with Canada and cooperation with Russia for fisheries enforcement. There is a need for new icebreakers and international cooperation for shipping regulations and oil spill prevention. Building new icebreakers, international cooperation for shipping regulations and oil spill prevention, and approval of the International Maritime Organization are essential to protect United States interests in the Arctic Ocean and adjacent seas. Starting these efforts now, following the completion of an Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment by the Arctic Council, is crucial due to the extensive current use of these waters by vessels from various nations. The Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment Implementation is crucial for protecting United States interests in the Arctic Ocean and adjacent seas. The purpose of this section is to ensure safe and secure maritime shipping in the Arctic, including aids to navigation, vessel escorts, spill response capability, and search and rescue. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard is encouraged to negotiate agreements through the International Maritime Organization to promote coordinated action among Arctic nations for marine safety and environmental protection. The Committee on the Maritime Transportation System is responsible for coordination. The Committee on the Maritime Transportation System coordinates domestic transportation policies in the Arctic for safe maritime navigation, including oil spill prevention, vessel tracking, and search and rescue. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard can enter agreements and contracts, promote icebreaking for safe navigation, and conduct demonstration projects. The Secretary of Transportation can enter agreements for demonstration projects to reduce emissions and train mariners for Arctic operations. Authorization of appropriations is provided for seasonal operations in the Arctic. Authorization of appropriations is provided for seasonal operations in the Arctic, including prevention of discharges. The Secretary of Transportation is allocated funds for demonstration projects to reduce emissions and train mariners for Arctic operations. Additionally, a comparative cost-benefit analysis of extending the service life of icebreakers is required within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The Commandant of the Coast Guard is required to conduct a cost-benefit analysis of extending the service life of existing icebreakers, constructing new ones, or a combination of both to carry out Federal icebreaking missions. Additionally, an analysis of the impact on mission capacity and presence in the Arctic regions through 2020 due to icebreaker fleet recapitalization is mandated. The Commandant of the Coast Guard must conduct a cost-benefit analysis of icebreaker fleet recapitalization for Federal icebreaking missions and assess the impact on mission capacity in the Arctic regions through 2020. A report with recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the completion of the High Latitude Study. The Commandant of the Coast Guard is required to submit a report with study results and recommendations to the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the House of Representatives Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. This report must be submitted within 1 year of the enactment of the Act. The Coast Guard must assess the need for increased presence in high latitude regions. The Secretary of the department overseeing the Coast Guard must submit a report to Congress within 270 days, evaluating the need for additional Coast Guard capabilities in high latitude regions across various mission areas. This includes assessing current assets, projected needs for forward operating bases, and requirements for infrastructure and resources to support operations in these regions. The report to Congress must include an assessment of projected needs for Coast Guard forward operating bases in high latitude regions, shore infrastructure requirements, personnel, logistics, communications, and resources. It should also evaluate the need for high latitude icebreaking capability, the performance of current icebreaking assets, and acquisition costs for necessary assets. The report to Congress must include an assessment of the material condition, safety, and working conditions aboard high latitude icebreaking assets, along with detailed cost estimates for acquisition, operations, and maintenance of additional prevention and response capability in high latitude regions. This includes estimates for renovating and modernizing the existing high latitude icebreaking fleet, as well as replacing it. The term "Arctic" in this Act is defined the same way as in the Arctic Research and Policy Act of 1984.
